content: The Act titled "Compete Act of 2007" includes provisions for internal control reporting and evaluation. The Compete Act of 2007 includes amendments to section 404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 regarding internal control reporting and evaluation by registered public accounting firms. The focus is on assessing the effectiveness of internal controls over financial reporting. The Compete Act of 2007 amends section 404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, requiring registered public accounting firms to assess internal controls over financial reporting. The attestation and report should not include a separate opinion on control effectiveness, with intervals for assessment every 3 years or sooner for major company changes. The Compete Act of 2007 amends section 404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, requiring registered public accounting firms to assess internal controls over financial reporting. The attestation standards issued by the Board focus on critical controls for financial statement accuracy, consistent with materiality standards set by the Commission. The Compete Act of 2007 amends section 404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, requiring registered public accounting firms to assess internal controls over financial reporting. The standards for determining the greatest risks to the company must be done in consultation with management and based on industry characteristics. The standards also allow auditors to rely on examinations and inspections conducted by federal and state authorities to avoid duplication. The Compete Act of 2007 amends Sarbanes-Oxley Act section 404, requiring accounting firms to assess internal controls over financial reporting. Inspections by regulatory agencies focus on issuer's risk-based internal controls. Third-party accountants can work with public accounting firms on determining controls to be tested. The Compete Act of 2007 amends Sarbanes-Oxley Act section 404, requiring accounting firms to assess internal controls over financial reporting. Registered public accounting firms rely heavily on third-party accountants during attestations to avoid repetitive testing. Management of the issuer must openly communicate with accounting firms on all aspects of internal controls. The Compete Act of 2007 amends Sarbanes-Oxley Act section 404, requiring accounting firms to assess internal controls over financial reporting. A third-party accountant, different from the one engaged for attestation, is defined. The Commission will establish a materiality standard based on the impact of internal controls on financial statements and the issuer's financial status. The Compete Act of 2007 amends Sarbanes-Oxley Act section 404, requiring accounting firms to assess internal controls over financial reporting. A third-party accountant is defined. The Commission will establish a materiality standard based on the impact of internal controls on financial statements and the issuer's financial status. SEC. 3. SMALLER PUBLIC COMPANY EXEMPTION FROM INTERNAL CONTROL PROVISION. Section 404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 is amended to include a new subsection regarding a Smaller Public Company Exemption. This exemption allows smaller public companies to voluntarily elect to comply with the requirements of the section for their annual report. If a smaller company chooses not to comply, they must disclose this noncompliance in their report. The term 'smaller public company' is defined for this purpose. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 allows for exemptions for smaller public companies with specific criteria related to market capitalization, revenue, and number of beneficial holders. SEC. 4. COMPETITION FOR AUDITING SERVICES. The Commission and the Board are required to conduct a study on the lack of competition in audit services for issuers. The study will focus on the concentration of audit performance in four large accounting firms, ways to increase the number of qualified firms, and methods to encourage partnerships among accounting firms. The Commission and the Board will submit a joint report within 6 months on the study required by this Act. The report will contain results of the examination of subjects identified and recommendations for measures to alleviate concentration in the accounting industry. The Commission and the Board will submit a joint report within 6 months on the study required by this Act, identifying measures to alleviate concentration in the accounting industry and making recommendations to Congress for necessary law changes. SEC. 5. PRINCIPALS-BASED GUIDANCE STUDY. The Commission and the Board will conduct a study comparing the principles-based Turnbull Guidance in Great Britain to section 404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002. Within one year, they will submit a joint report to specific committees, comparing the accounting and other costs of both systems. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 aims to reduce risk to investors and increase confidence in issuers' financial statements. Recommendations will be made to Congress to alleviate accounting costs related to these goals. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The terms "audit", "Board", "Commission", "issuer", and "public accounting firm" are defined in section 2 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002.
